title: If the Quran has been perfectly preserved in Arabic, why are there 26 different Arabic Qurans? - Quora

response.answer_text: We are cautioned against argument that insists on our personal opinions. The belief in our own rightness that makes others wrong can lead us into fighting, and not only fighting the kaafiruwn, but also each other. The presentation of fact may be called “lies,” and warning against arrogance can be dismissed with contempt. There is a common misunderstanding of the preservation of the Qur’an, a belief that has not been carefully investigated, that simply does not hold up when examined with care, and that is not only in “preservation” but in something called “perfect preservation,” which, if not defined creates mischief, where we may attach something true as a “lie,” which is kufr. We are not rescued from the Fire by exposing the errors or even the lies of others, and the behavior of the kaafiriyn is descibed for us not to condemn them, but to warn us against behaviors like that, which lead to doom if Allah does not forgive. Because the issue came up at a masjid, and because I happened to have a copy of two different “readings” of the Book, and a copy of the Taskhent mushhaaf, I prepared a document that showed actual variations. Just fact, verifiable. I was then prohibited by the imaam from talking to anyone at the masjid. When another member recited the Qur’an to him, he shouted angrily “No!” Thus his strong belief in his own rightness led him straight into blatant kufr. To the question here, the question proposes the the idea of “perfect preservation” but that is not defined; nevertheless it implies that There was a single text.We have that text, and any variation is not authentic.We have agreement on that.Critics of Islam, sometimes reacting to Muslim polemic over Biblical texts, use fact to counterattack, tempting us to attack fact as “lies.” However the problem with these facts on point is not the facts themselves but with how they are interpreted. First, some fact. That such and such a hadith exists is fact; in general, strong hadith exist in variations that share common elements, so we look for common elements. There are many ahadith that refer to “seven ahruf” often translated as “dialects,” but it literally means “letters,” and at the time of the Prophet, saws, the recitation marks, including vowels, had not been invented. The “readings,” then, include variations in vowels, which can affect meaning. This can be complicated by the use of “seven” in Arabic to mean ”many.” Sahih al-Bukhari Book of Virtues of the Qur'an Hadith 514 — Narrated 'Umar bin Al-Khattab: I heard Hisham bin Hakim reciting Surat Al-Furqan during the lifetime of Allah's Apostle and I listened to his recitation and noticed that he recited in several different ways which Allah's Apostle had not taught me. I was about to jump over him during his prayer, but I controlled my temper, and when he had completed his prayer, I put his upper garment around his neck and seized him by it and said, "Who taught you this Sura which I heard you reciting?" He replied, "Allah's Apostle taught it to me." I said, "You have told a lie, for Allah's Apostle has taught it to me in a different way from yours." So I dragged him to Allah's Apostle and said (to Allah's Apostle), "I heard this person reciting Surat Al-Furqan in a way which you haven't taught me!" On that Allah's Apostle ﷺ said, "Release him, (O 'Umar!) Recite, O Hisham!" Then he recited in the same way as I heard him reciting. Then Allah's Apostle ﷺ said, "It was revealed in this way," and added, "Recite, O 'Umar!" I recited it as he had taught me. Allah's Apostle then said, "It was revealed in this way. This Qur'an has been revealed to be recited in seven different ways, so recite of it whichever (way) is easier for you (or read as much of it as may be easy for you)." This is such a remarkable story. ‘Umar, ra, is “telling one on himself.” This shows his anger at what he believed was wrong, to the extent that he accused Hisham of lying.This translates “ahruf” as “different ways.” There is a problem with the common interpretation as “dialects,” as of seven tribes. ‘Umar and Hisham were both Qurayshi.Another related story: Hadith Ahruf: Quran revealed in seven readings, do not argue it | Daily Hadith Online الحديث اليومي Abu Juhaym reported: The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said, “The Quran is recited in seven ways. Do not argue over the Quran, for arguing over the Quran is an act of unbelief.” This is a comprehensive review of the issue of Ahruf: Understanding Seven Ahruf –1 (the weaker explanations) Understanding Seven Ahruf –2 (Best Explanation) Some other facts (from my memory): A single mus-haaf was collected by the order of Abu Bakr, ra, based on suhuwf (written pieces) and memory. This was likely using the Qurayshi dialect.This was reviewed under the order of ‘Uthmaan, ra and the two verses at the end of Sura 9 were added.Copies were made of this mus-haaf and distributed. As manual copies, it is likely that there would be occasional errors, such as might escape notice.I have seen at least one variation between the most popular reading Hafs, which many Muslims today believe is the only Qur’an, and Warsh, popular in North Africa (but not Egypt), where a different word is used. The change in meaning is minor or nonexistent.I have seen at least on letter variation between the Tashkent mus-haaf and the accepted texts, where there is siyn in place of Sad.“Perfect” is a strong word, not allowing any deviation at all.What we have is, from the history and the lack of major controversy among the early Muslims, an authentic text to be used for the purpose intended, which is to remind us of our relationship with Reality. Given the facts, it is not surprising that one may be able to find many variant texts, but it is irrelevant. The level of variation is trivial compared to that in other ancient texts, but the Qur’an and our prophet did not attack what was extant and followed of the Torah and Gospels, and the letters of Paul are what they, themselves, purported to be. It is not for us to judge those who seek the pleasure of God through another system. God will guide them as he wills, and anger and arrogance on our part will not guide anyone. Disrespect for the books sacred to others was forbidden, but some of us like to argue and make others wrong, which is distinct from warning against evil and inspiring with good. Avoiding these these tendencies of the reactive mind is the jihad fiy n-nafs. a -uwdhu billahi min ash-shayTaani r-rajiym wa llahu a^lam

The Quran appears to be of different versions not because the words are different but because the markings to aid pronunciation are different. Take a look at the following examples that are claimed to be different versions of the Quran:  The word said to be different is actually written the following way in the original Quran: كبير What you see above are not from the original Quran but are copies of the Quran with markings added. Even if there are small differences in these versions of the Quran with markings, it does not change the original Quran that has no markings. We need to be clear about this. Notice that there are no lines above or below the letters. Then, in order to make it easier for non-Arabic speakers, lines have been added by people to show how to pronounce the word. But does “big” and “a lot of” make a difference in understanding this verse? Of course not! But the original Quran remains the same - without lines above or below. An Arabic speaker will confirm this for whoever is in doubt. Here is a second example that is claimed to show differences:  The word in the original Quran is: قتل Again, in the original Quran there are no markings above or below. So it can be read either as Qatal or Qatil, and both would be correct - there are prophets who have fought or killed (such as Moses and David) and there are prophets who have been killed. The word قتل can mean kill, killing or was killed. So as you can see, the Quran remains the same. There is only one version. No word or letter has been changed. What has changed are markings that are added to later copies of the same Quran, to make reading easier for non-Arabic speakers.

response.answer_text: The Quran was revealed in seven different “ahruf.” This is reported in a well-known Sahih hadith: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said, "Gabriel recited the Qur'an to me in one way (one Harf). Then I requested him (to read it in another way), and continued asking him to recite it in other ways, and he recited it in several ways till he ultimately recited it in seven different ways (seven Ahruf)." (Sahih al-Bukhari) So, the existence of these variants is not due to a lack of preservation but due to a good preservation of what the Prophet Muhammad (SAW) actually taught. Today, we have 10 major qiraat (recitations) of the Quran. The question arises that 10 is larger than 7, so where did the the three more come from. The answer is that the qiraat aren’t the Ahruf. The qiraat are, instead, combinations of different Ahruf. For example, one qiraa can be half of Harf 1 and half of Harf 2. Through this combination, we have 10 major qiraat from the original 7 Ahruf. This combination is completely permissible because all the 7 Ahruf are equally valid as the Quran. Each of the 10 qiraat and their reciters had two major students who passed on mostly the same except they may have differed the Harf they chose for particular words in some places. So, in a sense, you can have 10x2=20 different ways of writing the Quran with all of them being completely valid. You can find all 20 on the internet here in audio form and in the “مصاحف” tab at the bottom of the page here in written form. It’s nothing hidden. As for the claimed number of “26,” I have no doubt some deception is going on. Either they have the same exact qiraat but with different colors on the cover, or they’re just deceiving the viewers (and perhaps themselves as well) by counting the same Quran as different. For example, near the end of the linked video, they count both the supposed “1924 Cairo Edition” and “Hafs ‘an Aasim” as two of their “versions.” However, the “1924 Cairo Edition” is just a publication of the qiraat of Hafs ‘an Aasim! Why would you count them differently? The publishers of Cairo only decided the specifics of how to write and and organize the text, and they did not change the text itself from Hafs ‘an Aasim. That is the kind of deceit (or confusion) you are dealing with in that video. These people have no idea what they are talking about.
